page.title: 09The Lighthouse
page.content: In 1814 the island was bought by the Commissioners of the Northern Lighthouse Board and has remained their property ever since. The Board erected a new Stevenson Lighthouse to replace the original coal beacon. The stationary oil light in this was replaced by a revolving shutter in 1843. In the same year a second lighthouse was built on the east coast of the island, known as the "low light". These lights operated until the North Carr Lightship was installed at the end of the century and the low light has since been converted into a bird observatory. In 1886 the main lighthouse was electrified and the dam erected to provide power. However, the electric light caused damage to migrant birds and in 1924 it was changed back to paraffin. Despite the lighthoses there were still wrecks.
